title.text: The 7th Workshop on the Innovative Use of NLP for Building Educational Applications, pages 208-215, Informing Determiner and Preposition Error Correction with Word Clusters

abstractContent.text: We extend our n-gram-based data-driven prediction approach from the Helping Our Own (HOO) 2011 Shared Task (Boyd and Meur-ers, 2011) to identify determiner and preposition errors in non-native English essays from the Cambridge Learner Corpus FCE Dataset (Yannakoudakis et al., 2011) as part of the HOO 2012 Shared Task.

entities.text: Cambridge Learner Corpus FCE Dataset (Yannakoudakis et al., 2011)

abstractContent.text: Our system focuses on three error categories: missing determiner, incorrect determiner, and incorrect preposition.
Approximately two-thirds of the errors annotated in HOO 2012 training and test data fall into these three categories.
To improve our approach, we developed a missing deter-miner detector and incorporated word clustering (Brown et al., 1992) into the n-gram prediction approach.

introductionContent.text: We extend our n-gram-based prediction approach () from the HOO 2011 Shared Task () for the HOO 2012 Shared Task.

This approach is an extension of the preposition prediction approach presented in Elghafari,, which uses a surface-based approach to predict prepositions in English using frequency information from web searches to choose the most likely preposition in a given context.

For each preposition in the text, the prediction algorithm considers up to three words of context on each side of the preposition, building a 7-gram with a preposition slot in the middle: rather a question the scales falling For each prediction task, a cohort of queries is constructed with each of the candidate prepositions in the slot to be predicted: 1.
rather a question of the scales falling 2.
rather a question to the scales falling 3.
rather a question in the scales falling . .
